cell.html: A science-fiction author and inventor . He contracted polio in February 1962, which confined him to bed for months. In 1988, he was diagnosed with post-polio syndrome. [98]
cell.text: A science-fiction author and inventor . He contracted polio in February 1962, which confined him to bed for months. In 1988, he was diagnosed with post-polio syndrome. [98]

cell.html: A scientist, inventor, and television pioneer, DuMont developed polio at age 11. While recovering from polio he began experimenting with electronics by building a radio transmitter and receiver out of an oatmeal box. [99]
cell.text: A scientist, inventor, and television pioneer, DuMont developed polio at age 11. While recovering from polio he began experimenting with electronics by building a radio transmitter and receiver out of an oatmeal box. [99]

cell.html: A psychiatrist who was influential in the modern practice of hypnosis and psychotherapy . He caught polio, aged 17, and was almost completely paralysed for a time. Erickson regarded his lengthy recovery as a learning experience. Later, post-polio syndrome paralysed his legs and an arm. [100]
cell.text: A psychiatrist who was influential in the modern practice of hypnosis and psychotherapy . He caught polio, aged 17, and was almost completely paralysed for a time. Erickson regarded his lengthy recovery as a learning experience. Later, post-polio syndrome paralysed his legs and an arm. [100]

cell.html: A physiologist noted for his work on cardiology . He caught polio in 1946 during his final year of medical residency training. Guyton's shoulders, left arm and right leg were paralysed. During nine months of recovery, he built many devices to aid the handicapped, for which he received a Presidential Citation. He remained severely crippled and could only walk with difficulty. [101]
cell.text: A physiologist noted for his work on cardiology . He caught polio in 1946 during his final year of medical residency training. Guyton's shoulders, left arm and right leg were paralysed. During nine months of recovery, he built many devices to aid the handicapped, for which he received a Presidential Citation. He remained severely crippled and could only walk with difficulty. [101]

cell.html: Little was the founder of the Royal Orthopaedic Hospital of London and the first to identify cerebral palsy . Around age two, Little was infected with poliomyelitis, from which he developed a deformed foot. He decided to go into the medical profession with the intention of finding a cure for his foot. [102] [103]
cell.text: Little was the founder of the Royal Orthopaedic Hospital of London and the first to identify cerebral palsy . Around age two, Little was infected with poliomyelitis, from which he developed a deformed foot. He decided to go into the medical profession with the intention of finding a cure for his foot. [102] [103]

cell.html: The first female aircraft designer in the world, MacGill was afflicted with polio at the age of 24. Although her disability brought an end to her dream of becoming a pilot , she insisted on going on all flight tests in order to best assess her aircraft designs. [104]
cell.text: The first female aircraft designer in the world, MacGill was afflicted with polio at the age of 24. Although her disability brought an end to her dream of becoming a pilot , she insisted on going on all flight tests in order to best assess her aircraft designs. [104]

cell.html: A mechanical engineer and chemist , Midgley developed chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and held over a hundred patents. He contracted polio at age 51, which left him severely disabled, and caused him to lose a leg. To help himself get out of bed, Midgley designed a system of ropes and pulleys; he died of strangulation in 1944 after becoming tangled in the ropes of his contraption. [105]
cell.text: A mechanical engineer and chemist , Midgley developed chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and held over a hundred patents. He contracted polio at age 51, which left him severely disabled, and caused him to lose a leg. To help himself get out of bed, Midgley designed a system of ropes and pulleys; he died of strangulation in 1944 after becoming tangled in the ropes of his contraption. [105]

cell.html: A physicist and protégé of Robert Oppenheimer , Morrison was the youngest member of the Manhattan Project . He contracted polio at the age of four, which left him partly handicapped, but also stimulated a love of science. [106]
cell.text: A physicist and protégé of Robert Oppenheimer , Morrison was the youngest member of the Manhattan Project . He contracted polio at the age of four, which left him partly handicapped, but also stimulated a love of science. [106]

cell.html: "One of the finest mathematicians of the nineteenth century", Noether studied algebraic geometry . He contracted polio at the age of 14 which left him permanently handicapped. [107]
cell.text: "One of the finest mathematicians of the nineteenth century", Noether studied algebraic geometry . He contracted polio at the age of 14 which left him permanently handicapped. [107]

cell.html: A physician , Rue contracted polio from a patient in 1954 (she was the last person in Oxford, England to get the disease). The disease left her with one useless leg but motivated her to become a champion for women in medicine. [108]
cell.text: A physician , Rue contracted polio from a patient in 1954 (she was the last person in Oxford, England to get the disease). The disease left her with one useless leg but motivated her to become a champion for women in medicine. [108]

cell.html: Schwartz, a mathematician , had a childhood brush with polio. [109]
cell.text: Schwartz, a mathematician , had a childhood brush with polio. [109]

cell.html: Siebert contracted polio as a young child, and was left with a slight limp. She went on to develop the Tuberculin antigen used in the standard Tuberculosis test . [110]
cell.text: Siebert contracted polio as a young child, and was left with a slight limp. She went on to develop the Tuberculin antigen used in the standard Tuberculosis test . [110]

cell.html: Whipple became an astronomer after a mild bout of polio thwarted his dream of becoming a professional tennis player. He is best known for his "dirty snowball" model of comets . [111]
cell.text: Whipple became an astronomer after a mild bout of polio thwarted his dream of becoming a professional tennis player. He is best known for his "dirty snowball" model of comets . [111]

cell.html: A sociologist , Whyte's specialty was his study of Boston's North End gangs. He caught polio in 1943. After two years of rehabilitation at the Roosevelt Warm Springs Institute for Rehabilitation , Whyte continued his field research; conducting all of his interviews with the aid of braces, crutches and cane. [112]
cell.text: A sociologist , Whyte's specialty was his study of Boston's North End gangs. He caught polio in 1943. After two years of rehabilitation at the Roosevelt Warm Springs Institute for Rehabilitation , Whyte continued his field research; conducting all of his interviews with the aid of braces, crutches and cane. [112]

context.text: List of poliomyelitis survivors - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Name Life Comments
Philip Morrison , who had polio as a child, became the youngest member of the Manhattan Project .
List of poliomyelitis survivors
Elsie MacGill caught polio in the same year she became the first Canadian woman to receive an Electrical Engineering degree.
[ edit ] Sports
[ edit ] Uncontested diagnosis
[ edit ] Retrospective diagnosis
[ edit ] Doubtful diagnosis
[ edit ] Mistakenly believed to have survived polio
[ edit ] Notes and references
Contents
[ edit ] Science and medicine
Robert McNamara 's career was changed when both he and his wife caught polio.
Ray Ewry , nicknamed "The Human Frog" for his ability to leap, spent some of his childhood in a wheelchair.
Former senator John Porter East contracted polio in 1955 while serving as a lieutenant in the United States Marines.
Kim Beazley was hospitalised with polio as a child.

This is an incomplete list , which may never be able to satisfy certain standards for completeness. Revisions and sourced additions are welcome. Itzhak Perlman , a polio survivor, plays the violin sitting down.
[ edit ] Politics
Wilma Rudolph made a remarkable recovery from childhood polio; she later won three Olympic gold medals.
Singer-songwriter Neil Young caught polio during an epidemic in the summer of 1951.
Cecil 'Skelly' Spence of Israel Vibration , a band founded by three polio survivors.
[ edit ] Visual arts
Saxophonist David Sanborn spent a year in an iron lung .

entity.htmlSnippet:
NameLifeComments
Arthur C. Clarke1917–2008A science-fiction author and inventor. He contracted polio in February 1962, which confined him to bed for months. In 1988, he was diagnosed with post-polio syndrome.[98]
Allen B. DuMont1901–1965A scientist, inventor, and television pioneer, DuMont developed polio at age 11. While recovering from polio he began experimenting with electronics by building a radio transmitter and receiver out of an oatmeal box.[99]
Milton H. Erickson1901–1980A psychiatrist who was influential in the modern practice of hypnosis and psychotherapy. He caught polio, aged 17, and was almost completely paralysed for a time. Erickson regarded his lengthy recovery as a learning experience. Later, post-polio syndrome paralysed his legs and an arm.[100]
Arthur Guyton1919–2003A physiologist noted for his work on cardiology. He caught polio in 1946 during his final year of medical residency training. Guyton's shoulders, left arm and right leg were paralysed. During nine months of recovery, he built many devices to aid the handicapped, for which he received a Presidential Citation. He remained severely crippled and could only walk with difficulty.[101]
William John Little1810–1894Little was the founder of the Royal Orthopaedic Hospital of London and the first to identify cerebral palsy. Around age two, Little was infected with poliomyelitis, from which he developed a deformed foot. He decided to go into the medical profession with the intention of finding a cure for his foot.[102][103]
Elsie MacGill1905–1980The first female aircraft designer in the world, MacGill was afflicted with polio at the age of 24. Although her disability brought an end to her dream of becoming a pilot, she insisted on going on all flight tests in order to best assess her aircraft designs.[104]
Thomas Midgley, Jr.1889–1944A mechanical engineer and chemist, Midgley developed chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and held over a hundred patents. He contracted polio at age 51, which left him severely disabled, and caused him to lose a leg. To help himself get out of bed, Midgley designed a system of ropes and pulleys; he died of strangulation in 1944 after becoming tangled in the ropes of his contraption.[105]
Philip Morrison1915–2005A physicist and protégé of Robert Oppenheimer, Morrison was the youngest member of the Manhattan Project. He contracted polio at the age of four, which left him partly handicapped, but also stimulated a love of science.[106]
Max Noether1844-1921"One of the finest mathematicians of the nineteenth century", Noether studied algebraic geometry. He contracted polio at the age of 14 which left him permanently handicapped.[107]
Rosemary Rue1928–2004A physician, Rue contracted polio from a patient in 1954 (she was the last person in Oxford, England to get the disease). The disease left her with one useless leg but motivated her to become a champion for women in medicine.[108]
Laurent Schwartz1915–2002Schwartz, a mathematician, had a childhood brush with polio.[109]
Florence Siebert1897–1991Siebert contracted polio as a young child, and was left with a slight limp. She went on to develop the Tuberculin antigen used in the standard Tuberculosis test.[110]
Fred Lawrence Whipple1906–2004Whipple became an astronomer after a mild bout of polio thwarted his dream of becoming a professional tennis player. He is best known for his "dirty snowball" model of comets.[111]
William Foote Whyte1914–2000A sociologist, Whyte's specialty was his study of Boston's North End gangs. He caught polio in 1943. After two years of rehabilitation at the Roosevelt Warm Springs Institute for Rehabilitation, Whyte continued his field research; conducting all of his interviews with the aid of braces, crutches and cane.[112]
